Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Autonomous and permanently deployed ship hull inspection and cleaning vehicle
Award.AbstractNarration: The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to improve efficiency in the shipping industry. Biofouling, or surface contamination on ships, increases drag and consequently makes travel inefficient. This project will develop an underwater robotic system that performs automated ship hull inspections and cleaning, increasing fuel efficiency by 10 percent and subsequently saving a container vessel $2 million annually. An automated cleaning solution improves safety and minimizes expensive human labor. The proposed innovation will maintain hull and coating performance; furthermore it will generate high-resolution images that can lead to improvements in coating design, as well as expensive and time-consuming dry-dock procedures. Beyond ship hull cleaning, automated cleaning technology has broad applications in vertical industrial inspection automation and military use. <br/><br/>This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will develop an autonomous and permanently deployed ship hull inspection and cleaning vehicle. This Phase 1 project will develop a low-cost sensor architecture and localization algorithm that can reliably place the vehicle on the hull. To date, there has been progress on large human-deployable robotic cleaning vehicles that can be an alternative to diver operations. However, these vehicles must be used at or close to a port, have complex filtration systems, are expensive and difficult to deploy, and require trained operators. During Phase I project, an autonomous magnetic crawling vehicle with a minimum cleaning speed of 0.25 m/s will be developed to test sensors for this application. Sensors identified as complementary and reliable will be integrated to position the vehicle on the hull using a probabilistic estimator. To ensure the vehicle optimizes its energy usage when submerged in a high drag environment, a key metric of success will be to accurately position the vehicle within 3 meters on the ship hull 95 percent of the time to minimize cleaning coverage overlap.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Currently over 90 percent of everything that we buy will travel on ships. Ships are responsible for roughly 3% of global CO2 and GHG emissions (CO2-eq), emitting approximately 1 billion tons of CO2 and GHGs per year, on average from 2007 to 2012. This emission is equivalent to 1/6th of the CO2 amount the US produced in 2017. Biofouling build-up, the accumulation of microorganisms, plants and algae on ship hulls, can increase the hydrodynamic drag of a ship by up to 60% and decrease its speed by 10% resulting in a fuel consumption increase of 40%. Simply reducing drag by 10% on ship container vessels worldwide would result in a $22B savings in fuel.

We propose the use of an autonomous underwater inspection and cleaning vehicle that allows ship operators to have transparency over the state of their hull, inspect and clean their vessels more frequently and reduce their fuel consumption and cleaning costs. During our Phase-I investigation, we successfully built a prototype hull-crawling robot and test environment, chose, and evaluated several sensors for location determination, and designed and tested a probabilistic location estimator.

We modified an off-the-shelf SeaDrone Inspector robot by removing the thrusters and adding two magnetic wheels with geared motor drives to attach and drive the robot along a vertical steel wall. We evaluated an array of sensors in the hull-tracking environment including optic flow sensors and algorithms, wheel position encoders, pressure sensors, accelerometer/gyro IMUs, and sonar-based sensors such as a DVL and USBL. Finally, we developed and tested an extended Kalman filter (EKF) to determine the location of the robot on a steel surface based on sensor inputs.

During this project, we collaborated with customers that service the shipping industry to further de-risk the commercialization of this system by evaluating market requirements and regulations. Even though the design and construction of a suitable form-factor robot is outside the scope of this Phase-I project, we have started to explore design concepts from what we have learned from this Phase-I study.
